combat is good, everything else sucks. 'bioshock' feels kinda slapped on in the same way cloverfield was slapped on to the cloverfield paradox. my impressions of the game weren't helped thanks to some overtuning on the developer's part near the end of the game (i was playing on hard).

as a bioshock game, 4/10.

as a turn-your-brain-off sort of game, 7/10.

This game is the one that will definitely be stuck in your mind after finishing it.

Story is the strongest side of this game. It's unusual, it's creative, it's interesting, it's well written. Characters have a lot of personality and they are evolving through the story, some of them to the best, others to the worst.

Gameplay was fun for me, I was never bored. As in any FPS you'll have different types of weapons for different range and playstyle. And also you'll have some abilities to enjoy. They also can be upgraded.
Progression is made well, as game gives new weapons and abilities even closely to story end.
I also liked their approach to companion. She is not immortal killing machine that will do everything for you, but also she is not useless burden that you need to hold by hand and escort from point A to point B. She is weak, she is not a warrior, but she can provide a support by giving you supplies and assisting with abilities specific only to her.

Due to the art style game looks good even in 2020. And steampunk flying city looks amazing and fun to explore.

So, after years of ignoring it, I've decided to finally play this game... and it's kinda mixed bag for me.

Pros:
- Visually it looks great and still holds up, it ran pretty well on my system, without any crashes or stutters what so ever.
- World is so detailed and beautiful, all the colors, different npc's, buildings etc. 
- Elizabeth and Booker's chemistry is great, and she as character is awesome. She can stand on her own plus help you out here and there.
- Voice acting is just superb, everyone nailed it.
- Gameplay is good, nothing mind blowing, but it still serves it's purpose. Running around, using all the Vigors and using the Skyline is pretty fun.
- Overall it's a polished, well made game with unique art style.

Cons:
- Story. I'm just not that fan of the [spoiler]"You wake up and it was all the dream"[/spoiler] type of things. 
I won't spoil anything, but I'm just not a fan of it.
- Game honestly should be shorter and it started to drag for me on the last third, especially the ending. That damn ending... IT. GOES. FOREVER. 
- No replay value. Game has A LOT of scripted sequences and dialogue scenes, which are okay for the first one or two playthroughs, but it gets old really fast if you want to play more. 
- My biggest killer and biggest reason for lower score is [spoiler] Lady Comstock [/spoiler] boss fight. It's such a terribly designed boss, especially on 1999 difficulty (the hardest one). Just terrible, it goes on for too long, basicaly a bullet sponge boss that spawns endless enemies over and over. It was so frustrating to deal with and it almost made me quit the game.

5/10 My final score. I still recommend this game, it's well made, polished, story driven game, that you should try it out once in a lifetime and never play it again.

As for the DLC's, there are Burial at Sea 2 episodes, that are tight and short episodes, which expand on the first games. Ending is really emotional and ties it all up nicely. Around 3-4 hours of content.
Last DLC is Clash in the Clouds, which is basically arenas that you fight waves of enemies. You earn money to upgrade your weapons and Vigors, and you can buy stuff at the museum for the display. There are 4 arenas total, with 15 waves on encounters in each.
Sometimes it can be challenging, especially if you are going for the blue ribbons, which I highly recommend, it's fun. There's no story or anything like that in it, it's just a "challenge mode".

8/10 for the DLC content.

"There is always a lighthouse, There's always a man, There's always a city"

Despite not having the most play time in my library, this is definitely the best game I have ever played! I'd argue the game is flawless in some aspects and the only complaints that I can muster are either A) 100% nitpicks, B) about as subjective as they come or C) Fairly minor things (In my opinion), however they could still potentially pull some people out of the experience, but before I elaborate on the flaws, let me tell you everything that this game gets right!

1. Story
The story in this game might not be as deep as the original Bioshock, but that doesn't mean it's necessarily worse. I don't want to disclose any details about the actual plot, as it is something that I would most definitely recommend you experience first hand without any prior knowledge, however I will state that the characters in this game are subjectively some of the best in all of video game history. Overall the story left me not only satisfies, but the ending stuck with me and I am completely unashamed to admit that I may have cried due to the ending. 

2. Gun play
The guns are impactful in the way they interact with enemies, visual design and sound (I will touch on those two topics later). The guns are satisfying to use as they have great recoil and do reasonable amounts of damage towards enemies, another thing that I like about the gun play is the fact that firing from the hip is often times just as accurate as aiming down sights, I like this, because it helps keep the pace up. 

3. General combat
Now this may seem like an extremely vague term, so let me clarify what I mean when I say "General combat". By general combat I am referring to things such as intensity and whether or not you need to use each of your abilities, and I am pleased to say that the general combat is excellent! I found myself using each of the Vigors (or Plasmids, if you're only familiar with the older bioshock games) very often (I played the game on hard, they might be less necessary on easier difficulties, but they're still a blast to use) the combat is also frantic as you will find yourself moving around the battle field looking for health pickups to keep you alive during combat

4. visual and audio design
This is something that I think the game does flawlessly, because of the fantastic art style, the visuals have aged like a fine wine and the audio is... REALLY good, I can't think of another way to word it without understating the quality of the audio, the soundtrack, voice acting and general sounds are just perfect!

-The negatives-

1. Some of the enemies are really irritating (The handymen spring to mind) and that can really have an impact on your opinion of the game,, but overall I'd argue it's not a very big problem

2. Death lacks any impact. You just lose a bit of money (something that's easy to come by) and your enemies regain some health, because you also regain salts (mana) upon death, it can occasionally come to your advantage even (I just find that a bit irritating, however some people might find that to be a plus, in which case, there's another positive for you!)

3. the latter half of the game has a few sections that some might find lacking (namely a boss fight with a certain character that really made me angry, and the last level (that I actually kind of liked, but a lot of people disliked it, so I'm including it anyway)) 

4. You don't move fast enough to avoid some projectiles, but that shouldn't affect your experience that badly, and hey, there's no shame in lowering the difficulty if they prove to get in your way! :)

Overall I would give this game a solid 9.5/10, I really hope this review helped inform your purchasing decision and I hope if you buy the game you enjoy it as much I did!
The main game is lame as hell but the Burial at Sea DLC is incredible! Would recommend that you play Bioshock 1 before this though! Bioshock 2 is also kinda lame, but not this bad.

I was really hyped for this game when it was first announced, but I felt underwhelmed by the finished game. The trailers and pre-release materials displayed so many things that were either scrapped from the final game or straight up embellished to make the game look different. What I liked about the first game was how ethical choices mattered and how every weird trait of the city had a pseudo-scientific explanation. When I was done with this game, I realized none of my choices really mattered and that I had so many questions that were never explained in any way.
El mejor bioshock para mi, mejora mucho la jugabilidad, no es tan repetitivo como sus antecesores, 100% recomendado
